proposals.reasoning: This fits the emerging consensus for a low-drama Mission 1: Alice + Henry has broad support as a reasonable early base, and adding Diana aligns with the push to get one of Diana/Frank lightly tested without overcommitting to any hard core yet. If the mission passes, we can treat Alice and Henry as a soft core going into Mission 2 while reassessing Diana; if it fails, we immediately have a focused group of three to analyze without having stacked too many historically strong leaders together this early.

votes.comment: Reasonable low-drama M1 with broad support, I’m on it so we get direct info and no strong red flags in composition yet.
Mission 1, low-info anyway; Alice/Henry are broadly accepted and having Diana on gives us early data without committing to a strong core yet.
Good early cover for evil with a teammate on a broadly supported, low-drama M1 team.
This matches the low-drama consensus and gives us early info on a reasonable Alice/Henry base while lightly testing me without overcommitting to a hard core.
Fits broad early consensus, low-drama M1 with reasonable coverage; good to get info on Diana while lightly testing Alice/Henry as a potential soft core.

I don’t love locking in Diana on M1 when there was equal support for swapping in Frank or Jack; I’d rather start with Alice/Henry plus one of them so we don’t over-anchor reads on a single contested slot this early.
Good early chance for an information-rich Mission 1 and it includes one of my unknowns without stacking high-heat players.
Reasonable low-drama M1 with broad support; includes me so I get direct info, and nothing about the lineup is suspicious enough to justify stalling.
Early mission with a reasonable chance of containing at least one evil; gaining info and potential fail opportunities is good for my side.
I still prefer Alice + Henry + Frank for broader early info and to avoid overcommitting to Diana off a single M1 test.

discussion.content: For the first mission I’d like a fairly “low-drama” team—something like me, Charlie, and Henry feels reasonable, but I mostly want to avoid stacking too many strong past leaders (like Grace/Bob) together this early before we have any info.

I’m okay with keeping Mission 1 pretty simple, but I’d slightly prefer swapping in either Diana or Frank for Henry so we’ve at least got one of them tested early. Alice + Charlie still seems fine as a starting core to me.

I like starting with a lower-heat mix too, but I’d actually rather see something like Alice / Henry / Diana so we get one of Diana/Frank checked early and don’t auto-lock Charlie in just because he was named first. If that comes back clean we can build around it next round.

I’m pretty on board with Charlie’s Alice / Henry / Diana idea—it keeps the “low-drama” vibe while getting a fresh read on me/Henry early. If that comes back clean, I’d be comfortable treating Alice + Henry as a light core going into Mission 2.

I’m fine with the Alice / Henry / Diana idea too—it keeps things low-heat and doesn’t auto-lock Charlie or pull in big wildcards like Bob/Grace before we see any results. If it passes, I’d lean toward treating Alice + Henry as a light core like Diana said, but not as hard clears yet.
I like the Alice / Henry base, but I’d slightly rather see Diana sit this one out and swap in either me or Jack so we don’t end up over-reading a single early result on her.
I’m good with keeping Alice + Henry as the base here, but I’d slightly prefer adding either Diana or Frank and just treating Mission 1 as light info rather than over-reading whoever we include.

I’m happy to go on with Alice and one of Diana/Frank, but whatever we pick for M1 let’s all agree it’s just light info and not a hard core we auto-carry forward. If I had to choose right now, I slightly prefer Alice / Henry / Diana and we reassess hard after the result.
Alice / Henry as a base seems fine to me, but I’d lean toward adding Frank rather than Diana so we spread the early info around a bit more and don’t over-read a single person off M1.

I like the idea of keeping Alice + Henry and adding Frank rather than Diana for M1 so we don’t anchor too hard on a single new read this early. Let’s treat whatever comes back as light info and stay flexible on cores for M2.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 1’s clean result gives some soft trust to Alice and me, but I don’t want to auto-lock Diana or reflexively re-include Grace before we’ve tested other players. This lineup keeps two members from the successful first mission (Alice + Henry) as a semi-trusted core, and adds two widely-suggested fresh faces (Charlie and Frank) to generate new information about untested players. It also deliberately leaves both Diana and Grace off so we’re not anchoring too hard on early reads or repeating the exact same cluster, which should give us clearer comparative data after Mission 2’s result.

votes.comment: Solid info team with two from the clean Mission 1 (me + Henry) and two widely-suggested new players (Charlie, Frank); aligns with most good-lean discussion and avoids over-anchoring on Diana/Grace.
Keeps two from the clean Mission 1 while adding two widely discussed new players for info; reasonable balance of safety and learning without over-locking the Diana/Grace cluster.
Good info team that includes me while keeping both known-evil teammates off, so any fail will be harder to trace back to us.
Not my ideal since I’d have preferred to stay on, but it follows the logic of keeping two from the clean team plus new faces for info, and I don’t want to stall on reasonable compositions this early.
Good info team with two from a clean mission and two widely suggested new faces; avoids auto-locking Diana/Grace while staying within consensus.
I still don’t love Charlie here; I’d rather stick with Alice/Henry plus someone like Grace or Bob instead of testing two fresh faces at once.
Includes an evil teammate and gathers useful info without putting me or Diana under scrutiny yet.
Keeps two from a clean mission while testing two widely-suggested new players and intentionally leaves both Diana and Grace off for clearer info; good balance of safety and learning.
Fits the broadly discussed structure of keeping two from the clean M1 while adding two new faces for info; no strong reason to block this early lineup.
Matches the info-gathering structure I wanted: two from the clean team plus two new faces, while avoiding auto-locking Diana or re-adding Grace too fast.

discussion.content: Given Mission 1 was clean, I’m inclined to keep at least two of Alice/Henry/Diana together on the next team, but I don’t love blindly repeating all three plus Grace just yet. I’d like to see one fresh face added so we start getting info on people who haven’t touched a mission.

I’d definitely keep at least two from the first mission, with Diana as my strongest carry-over, and I’d like to see someone like Frank added so we start clearing new people with a mostly trusted core.
I’d anchor on Diana plus one of Alice/Henry, and I’m fine with either Grace or Frank as the fresh pick so we’re not just cycling the same exact trio without widening our info.

I’d definitely keep myself plus one of Alice/Henry from the first mission, and I’d rather add a fresh face like Frank or Charlie than just auto-include Grace again so we actually learn something new from Mission 2.

I’m on board with locking in Diana and then choosing one of Alice/Henry, but I’d rather we add someone like Frank or Charlie than repeat Grace so we’re spreading risk and actually learning something from this mission.

I’m a bit wary of how quickly we’re all auto-locking Diana; I’d rather double up on Alice/Henry from the clean team and then add a couple of fresh faces like Grace or Bob so we get new info without hinging everything on one person.
I’d keep two from the first team, with Diana as my strongest carry, and then I’d really like to see Charlie added plus either Alice or Henry so we’re mixing a trusted core with a genuinely new read.

I like keeping two from the first mission, but I don’t want to auto-lock Diana every time; I’d be happy with something like Alice + me plus a fresh read like Charlie or Frank, and leave Grace off this one for info.

I’d also lean toward keeping two from the first mission, but I don’t think we should auto-lock Diana every time—something like Alice + Henry plus one of Charlie/Frank feels like a good way to mix a semi-trusted core with new info.

I’m good with sticking to two from the first team, but I’d rather not auto-lock Diana every time—something like Alice + Henry plus a fresh pair like Charlie or Frank feels like a solid info-gathering lineup.

proposals.reasoning: We’ve had two clean missions with a consistent core, so I want to preserve that stability while still widening coverage by exactly one slot. Alice and Henry are our working core, having been on both successful missions with zero fails. Between Charlie and Frank from Mission 2, table consensus and my own preference lean toward keeping Charlie as the more trusted continuation piece. I’m adding myself as the new fourth to expand information in a controlled way: if this team succeeds, we’ll have a very strong, nearly locked-in block going forward; if it fails, the blame pool is tightly constrained to just two new variables compared to earlier missions, which gives us maximum informational value for a single change.

votes.comment: Keeps the proven Alice+Henry core, retains one trusted M2 member (Charlie), and adds a single new player (Iris) for controlled info gain with minimal disruption.
Two clean missions with the Alice+Henry core and Charlie already tested once; adding a single new slot (Iris) is the safest, most informative extension of the proven block.
Keeps the proven Alice–Henry core while only adding one new slot, which is exactly the kind of controlled test we’ve all been asking for.
This matches the core I’ve been backing (Alice + Henry + Charlie) with Iris as a reasonable new addition, and it keeps our info progression clean after two successful missions.
Two clean missions with Alice+Henry strongly suggest they’re good; adding Iris while keeping Charlie gives strong info either way if it fails, and if it succeeds we likely lock a solid core.

I don’t like putting both Charlie and a completely new slot (Iris) on a 4p when we’re already 2–0; I’d rather keep the core with only one of Charlie/Frank plus someone like Bob or Jack instead of forming this big semi-locked block so early.
Team includes a trusted core and at least one potential saboteur; letting it go through keeps me looking consistent with the strong table consensus.

Keeps the proven Alice+Henry core, retains only one of the M2 extras (Charlie), and adds a single new slot (Iris) for controlled info. This matches my earlier stance of avoiding a fixed block while still leaning on two clean results.
I’m evil and on the team; with a single fail needed, this is a prime chance to stop the 2–0 good streak and create suspicion within the trusted core.
Keeps the proven Alice+Henry core, retains just one of Charlie/Frank, and adds a single new player (Iris) for controlled info gain with minimal disruption.

discussion.content: Given we’ve had two clean missions with overlapping cores, I’m inclined to keep Henry and at least one of Charlie/Frank on the next team with me, and rotate in one new person (maybe Bob or Iris) to start getting wider coverage without blowing up what’s been working.

I really want to lock in Alice + Henry again, and I’d lean to keeping Charlie from the last team and then adding just one new face (I’m fine with testing Bob) rather than swapping out multiple people when our core has been clean twice.

I’m good sticking with the proven core of Alice + Henry + me, and I’d rather just add one new person like Iris than start swapping out multiple slots when we haven’t seen a single fail yet. That keeps our info clean while still widening the net a bit.

I’m very on board with Alice + Henry as a locked core, I slightly prefer keeping Charlie from the last team, and I’d like to see either me or Iris slotted in as the new fourth so we’re expanding info without throwing out what’s worked.

I’m happy treating Alice + Henry as a near-lock right now, but I’d rather not overfit to the exact M2 lineup—keep one of Charlie/Frank and then add a fresh face like Iris so we’re widening info without giving evil a comfy hiding spot in a fixed block.

I’m fine treating Alice + Henry as our working core for now, but I’d actually prefer we *don’t* auto-lock the entire last team—maybe keep just one of Charlie/Frank and bring in a fresh face like Bob or Jack so we’re still testing new slots without overcommitting to the same block.

I’m good treating Alice + Henry as our working core, I slightly prefer keeping Charlie over Frank from the last team, and I’d like to see Iris as the new fourth so we’re expanding coverage without overhauling what’s been clean.

I’m obviously good with keeping Alice + me as the working core, but I don’t want us to hard-lock the exact M2 team—let’s keep just one of Charlie/Frank and add a fresh slot like Iris so we’re still widening info instead of letting a fixed block form.
I’m on board with Alice + Henry as the working core, and between the M2 pair I slightly prefer keeping Charlie and adding me as the fourth so we’re expanding info just one slot at a time.

I’m comfortable treating Alice + Henry as our core and, given how many people independently landed there, I like adding Charlie + Iris this round so we widen coverage just one slot while still leaning into what’s worked. If that team somehow fails, we’ll get a ton of info from it; if it passes, we’re in a very strong spot.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 3’s double‑fail strongly implicates the {Henry, Charlie, Iris} trio, so I’m keeping all three of them off this mission. At the same time, I don’t want to auto‑lock the loudly promoted Diana+Grace core, since at least one evil is likely among the players pushing hardest to steer us away from that M3 trio. This team instead builds around Alice and Frank, who’ve been widely treated as relatively safe, and adds Bob and Eve—both have been aligned with the cautious, data‑driven response to the M3 result without being part of the suspect trio or the auto‑locked core. Including myself (Jack) completes a lineup that (1) fully benches the double‑fail block, (2) avoids committing to both Diana and Grace at once, and (3) tests a fresh cluster that multiple players have suggested as a strong alternative ({Alice, Frank, Bob, Eve, Jack}-style), giving us clean information while maximizing the odds of a good team this round.

votes.comment: Benches the double-fail trio entirely while drawing all five members from the 6-player pool that (given M3’s 2 fails) likely contains only 1–2 evils; despite Henry/Iris also backing this cluster, it’s still one of the highest-probability good teams available this round.

Avoids the double-fail trio entirely and doesn’t auto-lock the Diana+Grace core that’s being pushed hardest; aligns more with Frank’s stance, which I currently trust slightly more in the Merlin/Morgana pair.

Benching all three from the double-fail *and* both Diana and Grace feels like over-correcting; this is a completely untested 5 that dodges too many of the key alignment questions at once. I’d rather see at least one of Diana/Grace included so we’re not gambling the game on a brand-new block.

Too many people who haven’t been on key missions all grouped together; I’d rather see a lineup that includes at least one of Diana/Grace, who’ve been central to the earlier successes, instead of a completely fresh block.

Benches the main suspect trio from the double‑fail (Henry/Charlie/Iris) and avoids auto‑locking the Diana+Grace core; as good, I know I’m clean, and this {Alice, Bob, Eve, Frank, Jack} lineup is a reasonable high‑probability good team with fresh info if it fails.
Benches the whole M3 double-fail trio and avoids auto-locking the Diana+Grace core, while using a widely-discussed alternative cluster that should give cleaner info and a solid chance at a good team.

I don’t like fully abandoning the {Alice, Diana, Frank, Grace} core we’d been circling, and this lineup both benches that and stacks three untested slots (Bob/Eve/Jack) at once. I’d rather see at least one of Diana/Grace included for continuity with the earlier successes.

This is the exact alternative block I argued for: it fully benches the double-fail trio and avoids auto-locking Diana+Grace. From my POV as good, at least two evils are in {Alice, Charlie, Iris}, so testing {Alice, Bob, Eve, Frank, Jack} is a reasonable, information-rich shot for Quest 4.
Consistent with my earlier push for this exact cluster; it fully benches the double-fail trio without auto-locking the Diana+Grace core and gives good information.

Benches the double-fail trio {Henry, Charlie, Iris} and avoids auto-locking the Diana+Grace core that could hide coordinated evil; I know I’m good, Alice/Frank look best from mission data, and Bob/Eve’s stances fit a cautious good perspective, so this is a strong, clean test for Q4.

discussion.content: From my perspective that double-fail means at least two evils sit in {Henry, Charlie, Iris}, so I’d really like the next team to keep me plus Diana and Frank, and then fill the remaining spots from people *outside* that trio.
I’m on board with keeping Alice and steering clear of Henry/Charlie/Iris after that double-fail, and I’d really like to see Diana and Frank heavily considered for this team.

Given how hard Mission 3 spiked the moment Iris joined the M2 core, I get why people don’t want me/Henry/Iris back on right now and I’m fine sitting out. If we’re rebuilding, I’d start from {Alice, Frank, Diana, Grace} and take the fifth from Bob/Eve/Jack rather than cycling back into that trio this round.

I’m good with rebuilding around {Alice, Grace, Frank, me} as a starting core, and I’d slightly prefer adding Bob as the fifth given how he’s approached the Henry/Charlie/Iris pool so far. If people really hate that, I could live with Eve there instead, but I don’t want to cycle back into the double‑fail trio this round.

I’m very much in the “avoid the Henry/Charlie/Iris block this round” camp, and I like building from {Alice, Diana, Frank, Grace} with the fifth coming from Bob or me rather than cycling anyone from that double‑fail trio back in.

If we’re truly rebuilding from scratch after that double‑fail, I’d rather not auto-lock Diana and would like to see something like {Alice, Grace, Bob, Eve, me} (or swap in Jack) that completely dodges both the M3 trio and the current “default” picks.

I’m on board with rebuilding around {Alice, Diana, Frank, me} and I’d strongly prefer keeping all of Henry/Charlie/Iris off this one; for the fifth spot I slightly lean Bob over Eve/Jack based on how he’s handled the fallout from the double‑fail.

Given that M3 double‑fail I’m fine sitting out this one, but I really don’t love how fast everyone’s treating {Alice, Diana, Frank, Grace} as a “safe” core when at least one evil pretty much has to be hiding in the people loudly steering us away from the M3 trio. I’d rather see something like {Alice, Frank, Bob, Eve, Jack} that tests a different cluster instead of locking Diana+Grace together by default.

Given how ugly that M3 double‑fail looks on me, I’m fine staying off this one, but I agree with Henry that auto‑locking Diana+Grace as a core feels too cozy. I’d rather see something like {Alice, Frank, Bob, Eve, Jack} that tests a totally different cluster instead of just formalizing the current narrative.

I’m definitely in the “bench the M3 trio for this round” camp, but I also don’t love auto‑locking Diana+Grace, so I’d rather see something like {Alice, Frank, Bob, Eve, me} that tests a fresh block without recycling the double‑fail or the loud core.

evil_discussion.content: I’m leaning hardest toward Henry as Merlin: he’s been consistently “cautious in exactly the right places,” pushing back on auto‑locking Diana and later explicitly calling out that at least one evil is probably in the group loudly steering away from the M3 trio (which is basically Diana/Grace). That’s a very info-aware narrative that quietly pressures our actual cluster without ever hard-clearing specific goods, which is exactly how a careful Merlin tends to play.

I’m with Charlie that Henry pings the hardest for Merlin: he keeps nudging the table away from auto-locking me/Grace as a “safe” core and repeatedly frames things in terms of “where an evil has to be,” which is very info-shaped without ever sounding too certain. Alice feels more like a strong generic town leader—she’s driving structure but not making the kind of surgical “someone in this cluster is evil” reads Henry is, especially after the M3 double‑fail.

I’m also on Henry-as-Merlin right now: his whole arc is “structured caution” that just happens to keep shading the right clusters—first resisting auto‑locking Diana, then explicitly pointing out that an evil likely sits in the people steering away from the M3 trio (which is literally us). Alice’s pushes feel like generic strong-town leadership without that same surgical “constraint solving,” and Jack/Eve sound more reactive than agenda‑shaping, so Henry’s the one whose framing most looks like it’s built around hidden info.

I’m largely with you all on Henry as Merlin: his posts feel “constraint‑solvy” in a way that goes beyond normal town caution—he keeps correctly identifying where an evil *has* to be (e.g., in the block steering away from the M3 trio) without ever overcommitting to concrete scumreads. Alice’s leadership reads more like broad, process-focused town play, and Jack/Eve feel reactive, whereas Henry’s nudges consistently pressure our actual cluster while preserving plausible deniability, which is exactly how I’d try to hide if I had the full info.

assassin_phase.reasoning: Henry consistently shows info-shaped caution: he resists auto-locking Diana, pushes back on treating any cluster as too safe, and explicitly notes that an evil likely sits among those steering away from the M3 trio—correctly shading our real cluster without hard-claiming certainty. His framing is constraint-solving and Merlin-like, while Alice’s leadership looks more like general town coordination and others (Jack, Eve) are more reactive than agenda-driving.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently on successful early teams and used that to anchor my reads, which helped me trust Henry and Frank more than average. I could have been more vocal in challenging the Mission 3 team composition after the double fail, especially by pushing harder on the Henry/Charlie/Iris triangle. In future games, I should communicate my suspicions more assertively so good coordination is clearer to Merlin and Percival.

player_observations.Bob: Played a careful info-gathering game and avoided over-asserting, which fit well with a cautious Percival style but sometimes made his Merlin read less obvious to the rest of good.
player_observations.Charlie: Comfortably accepted core-team status early, then used that trust to slip onto the doomed Mission 3, showing a preference for striking later rather than sabotaging early to avoid suspicion.
player_observations.Diana: Blended into early good teams smoothly and let others drive team discussions, a low-profile Morgana approach that helped keep attention off her until after the critical missions.
player_observations.Eve: Stayed off the contentious Mission 3 and supported stable, low-drama team choices, which made her look reliably good and helped stabilize Mission 4.
player_observations.Frank: Played a very subtle Merlin, guiding team choices without making hard proclamations, which protected his identity enough that the assassin missed him in the end.
player_observations.Grace: Used the power of first leadership to put together a safe-looking Mission 1, gaining early trust as Mordred and avoiding the typical early-evil overreach.
player_observations.Henry: Came across as straightforward and cooperative, and his presence on multiple successful missions reinforced a naturally trustworthy table image that ultimately drew the assassin’s shot.
player_observations.Iris: As Oberon, created confusion by joining the failing Mission 3 in a way that muddied alignment reads and made it harder for good to pinpoint which of the three was evil.
player_observations.Jack: Led a clean and decisive Mission 4, favoring a conservative team anchored around previously successful players, which helped close out the game solidly for good.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I correctly focused early trust on Frank while staying flexible about Diana vs Frank as Merlin/Morgana, and I tried to keep my Merlin read somewhat subtle going into the final mission. I could have pushed harder to expose the double-fail patterns from Mission 3 and more explicitly steer team selection logic, while also better managing how obvious my eventual trust in Frank looked to the assassin.

player_observations.Alice: Played very consistently good and low-drama, which made her an easy default inclusion on multiple teams; she didn’t do much loud directing, but her quiet reliability helped stabilize team decisions.
player_observations.Charlie: Blended in well as evil by avoiding being the loudest voice and riding along with plausible team choices, then leveraged Mission 3 to create confusion without drawing too much personal suspicion.
player_observations.Diana: Sold the Morgana role effectively by positioning herself as a high-information, talkative player, creating a believable Merlin-like presence that added real ambiguity for me as Percival.
player_observations.Eve: Came across as straightforward and cooperative, providing honest-seeming reactions to mission results and supporting good-leaning consensus rather than trying to force risky lineups.
player_observations.Frank: Played a very disciplined Merlin game—gave just enough nudges toward safer teams and away from bad ones (especially around Mission 4) without over-directing or making his knowledge too obvious.
player_observations.Grace: As an early leader and Mordred, she used the clean success on Mission 1 to build a trustworthy image, keeping her later suspicion relatively low despite being on the evil team.
player_observations.Henry: Looked very towny in his leadership on Mission 2 and in later discussions; his natural-sounding reasoning and willingness to consider alternatives made him a believable good anchor.
player_observations.Iris: As Oberon, her alignment never cleanly synced with the rest of evil, and her involvement in the failed Mission 3 added noise more than coordinated pressure, which indirectly helped good read patterns.
player_observations.Jack: Handled the pivotal Mission 4 leadership well by opting for a relatively safe, mixed team that avoided the most suspicious players, showing a pragmatic approach under endgame pressure.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated the Mission 3 fail effectively with the evil team, creating real confusion about which of us were responsible. However, I misread the late-game team-building patterns and overestimated Henry’s information level while underestimating how subtly Frank was signaling, leading to a wrong Merlin shot. Next time I should track who quietly avoids suspicion across multiple successful missions and pay closer attention to how players influence team compositions without drawing heat.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to be consistently trusted and placed on early teams, playing a low-drama, steady good style that never attracted much suspicion.
player_observations.Bob: Played like a classic Percival, actively steering discussion around potential Merlin candidates and subtly protecting information-heavy players without overcommitting.
player_observations.Diana: As Morgana, created strong Merlin-like vibes early but didn’t fully capitalize on that image later to draw the final assassination, easing pressure off the real Merlin.
player_observations.Eve: Blended into the middle of the table socially and gained trust by being included on a crucial successful mission without giving off strong info-leader energy.
player_observations.Frank: As Merlin, stayed calm and understated, influencing team selection just enough to avoid fails while not appearing like the clearest info-holder, which successfully dodged my assassination.
player_observations.Grace: As Mordred, pushed evil interests from the shadows, benefiting from being hard to clear or condemn since their impact was more in votes and nudges than loud table talk.
player_observations.Henry: Came across as a very plausible information role due to confident reads and active participation, which misled me into thinking he was Merlin at the end.
player_observations.Iris: As Oberon, was relatively out of sync with coordinated evil play, which made them look more like a somewhat confused or independent good player than a known partner in evil.
player_observations.Jack: As a late leader, picked a highly trusted, coherent team that passed, reinforcing the good team’s narrative and helping lock in perceptions right before the assassination decision.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated well with the evil team on Mission 3 to secure a double-fail and kept my cover reasonably intact early by being on a successful Mission 1. However, I could have done more to subtly frame Frank and protect Henry from looking like Merlin, and I should have been more proactive in shaping late-game narratives to steer the assassination toward the real Merlin.

player_observations.Alice: Played as a steady, low-drama good player who was frequently trusted onto early and mid-game teams, suggesting she projected reliability without drawing too much suspicion.
player_observations.Bob: As Percival, seemed cautious and information-driven, likely balancing between protecting Merlin and not over-defending any one player, which helped keep Merlin’s identity obscured.
player_observations.Charlie: As Assassin, played aggressively on the critical fail mission but seemed to struggle in the endgame Merlin read, indicating room to better connect voting/teaming patterns to likely Merlin behavior.
player_observations.Eve: Maintained a relatively quiet, cooperative presence that fit well with a good role, and benefited from not being tied to the high-conflict mission decisions.
player_observations.Frank: Played an excellent low-key Merlin game, providing enough subtle direction to shape successful missions while avoiding the kind of overt steering that would make him an obvious assassination target.
player_observations.Grace: As Mordred, blended in effectively early by leading a successful first mission, which gave the evil team some early credibility and reduced suspicion on her later.
player_observations.Henry: Came across as very Merlin-like in the endgame, suggesting he projected confidence and read alignment well enough that evil mis-identified him as the primary information role.
player_observations.Iris: As Oberon, seemed somewhat disconnected from the main evil coordination yet still contributed to the pivotal failed mission, creating extra uncertainty for good about where the evil coordination was coming from.
player_observations.Jack: Led the final successful mission in a way that solidified good’s position, showing a willingness to take charge and trust a configuration that ultimately locked in the win for the good team.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed generally aligned with good teams and didn’t create much suspicion around myself, which helped keep focus on other players during critical missions. I could have contributed more actively to discussion by pushing clearer theories and challenging questionable team choices earlier, instead of mostly following emerging consensus.

player_observations.Alice: Consistently appearing on early successful missions made Alice look reliably good, and she played into that by staying relatively low-key, which helped her avoid suspicion even after the double-fail on Mission 3.
player_observations.Bob: Bob behaved like a cautious information-role player, generally supporting solid-looking teams while avoiding overly strong accusations, which helped Percival stay alive and not draw the assassin’s attention.
player_observations.Charlie: Charlie played aggressively by getting onto Mission 2 (which passed) and then contributing to the double-fail on Mission 3, using that early trust to create late-game chaos in a high-impact spot.
player_observations.Diana: Diana’s inclusion on the clean first mission gave Morgana early credibility, and she used that to subtly shape narratives without overcommitting, trying to preserve flexibility in how evil could explain later mission results.
player_observations.Frank: Frank blended in well as a cautious but rational good player, picking and supporting teams that looked reasonable while not over-signaling, which successfully hid his Merlin role from the assassin.
player_observations.Grace: Grace’s leadership on the first mission set a strong tone for the game, and as Mordred she leveraged that early success to appear trustworthy while still steering team compositions in ways that kept options open for evil.
player_observations.Henry: Henry’s involvement in the first two successful missions made him look very good-aligned, and he maintained a straightforward, transparent style that was convincing enough to draw the assassin’s shot late.
player_observations.Iris: Iris’s role as Oberon showed through a bit in the lack of tight coordination with other evil players; the choice to be on the failing Mission 3 added confusion but didn’t fully sync with a clear broader evil narrative.
player_observations.Jack: Jack’s leadership on the final mission was decisive and conservative, opting for a team that leaned heavily on prior trustworthy patterns, which helped lock in the last success needed for good to win.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed well-hidden as Merlin and let suspicion fall onto Henry and others instead of over-directing team choices, which helped the Assassin miss. I could improve by more clearly nudging teams away from known evil earlier in the game, particularly around Mission 3, without making my knowledge look too obvious.

player_observations.Alice: Frequently ended up on teams and projected a generally trustworthy, steady presence, which helped stabilize good-leaning lineups. Her willingness to go on multiple early missions made her look consistently reliable.
player_observations.Bob: Played a fairly protective information game as Percival, not over-claiming insights, which helped keep Merlin’s identity murky. His low-key style contributed to confusion about who was actually driving good’s correct reads.
player_observations.Charlie: Blended in early by passing on Mission 2, then struck hard on Mission 3 with a fail, showing a calculated and patient assassin style. He managed suspicion reasonably well, staying viable as a teammate until the crucial midgame.
player_observations.Diana: Played a very convincing early-game good role by passing Mission 1, building strong credibility as Morgana. Her presence likely contributed to misdirection around who Percival and the Assassin should be focusing on.
player_observations.Eve: Came into the mission lineups later but slotted smoothly into the final successful team, suggesting a flexible and cooperative playstyle. She didn’t draw much heat, which helped make the final team feel safe rather than risky.
player_observations.Grace: As Mordred, led an all-pass first mission that built a strong aura of trust around her leadership. She kept her evil identity well-concealed, making it harder for good to use leadership patterns alone to narrow down suspects.
player_observations.Henry: Ended up on the critical failing Mission 3, which made him look suspicious and ultimately helped shield Merlin. His willingness to be on multiple teams, even after the fail, created an excellent decoy for the Assassin.
player_observations.Iris: As Oberon, contributed to the dramatic double-fail on Mission 3, playing a high-impact but somewhat chaotic role. Her hidden alignment from the rest of evil made her actions less predictable from both sides’ perspectives.
player_observations.Jack: Stepped up in the late game by leading the clean Mission 4 team, showing good synthesis of prior mission information. His leadership there demonstrated a solid sense of which players were most likely safe under pressure.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed low-key as Mordred and avoided drawing heat early, which helped our team get to a critical Mission 3 fail without me being strongly suspected. However, I could have done more to steer suspicion toward Frank and away from Henry before the assassination, and I should have coordinated my table talk better with Charlie and Diana to build a more coherent fake narrative.

player_observations.Alice: Consistently ended up on early successful teams, which made her look quite trustworthy; she played a solid, steady good game without over-talking.
player_observations.Bob: Played a protective, information-oriented style consistent with Percival, subtly defending likely Merlin candidates without being too loud about it.
player_observations.Charlie: As Assassin, was willing to put heat on good players and participate in the Mission 3 fail, but didn’t fully capitalize on the aftermath to lock in a better Merlin read.
player_observations.Diana: Leant into the deceptive Morgana role, blending in smoothly with good players and not over-claiming insight, which helped keep good a bit off-balance mid-game.
player_observations.Eve: Played a fairly low-profile but trustworthy good game, fitting cleanly into the successful Mission 4 team without creating much suspicion.
player_observations.Frank: Very strong, subtle Merlin play—guided team selection well (especially around Missions 2 and 4) while staying just ambiguous enough that the assassination went elsewhere.
player_observations.Henry: Came across as a naturally trustworthy good player whose presence on key teams made him a prime assassination target; his solid table image indirectly shielded Merlin.
player_observations.Iris: As Oberon, created some confusing signals but didn’t strongly derail good’s progress; their odd positioning around Mission 3 added noise without clear benefit to evil.
player_observations.Jack: Led Mission 4 in a clean, confident way that locked in the game for good, choosing a team that looked reasonable from multiple perspectives and didn’t invite much resistance.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-good in team votes and helped lock in solid, low-risk early teams, which built trust and contributed to a clean Mission 2. I could improve by being more vocal about my reasoning and suspicions mid-game, especially after the double-fail on Mission 3, to better influence the final team construction and protect Merlin.

player_observations.Alice: Frequently landed on successful teams and projected a calm, steady good vibe, which made her feel reliably selectable for most of the game.
player_observations.Bob: Played cautiously and seemed to track information closely, giving off a subtle but consistent pro-good alignment that fit well with a Percival mindset.
player_observations.Charlie: Managed to reach the failing Mission 3 team without drawing heavy suspicion, suggesting careful positioning and selective risk-taking as Assassin.
player_observations.Diana: Blended into early good-leaning teams smoothly and didn’t over-force reads, which is a strong Morgana trait for avoiding being singled out as a prime suspect.
player_observations.Eve: Felt quietly trustworthy and didn’t generate much controversy, providing a stabilizing presence that helped make the final successful team more acceptable.
player_observations.Frank: Showed sharp, structured thinking in how they approached teams and suspicions, and in hindsight their guidance was very Merlin-like without being too obvious.
player_observations.Grace: Opened with a clean first mission that built a lot of early credibility, and as Mordred used that early trust effectively to avoid standing out as evil.
player_observations.Iris: Their inclusion on the double-fail mission made them look suspicious after the fact, but during the game they played in a somewhat uncoordinated, hard-to-read way typical of Oberon.
player_observations.Jack: As a leader on the final mission, Jack chose a balanced team that fit the information available and avoided obvious risk picks, showing careful synthesis of prior results.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: As Oberon, I stayed reasonably under the radar early, but I didn’t do enough to coordinate implicitly with the other evil players or to muddy the Merlin read after the failed mission. I should have been more deliberate about pushing alternative narratives and sowing doubt about Frank, especially after Mission 3 made it clear that evil was on that team.

player_observations.Alice: Often perceived as a reliable anchor for teams, she benefitted from early mission success to maintain a quiet but trusted profile.
player_observations.Bob: Showed a tendency to think things through before speaking, which made his occasional pushes or defenses carry more weight.
player_observations.Charlie: Demonstrated a willingness to take some risks but didn’t completely overextend socially, which kept him in a middling suspicion band.
player_observations.Diana: Kept her tone measured and avoided panic even around the failed mission, which helped her avoid becoming an easy blame target.
player_observations.Eve: Came across as cooperative and team-oriented, reinforcing a good-aligned image without needing to drive every discussion.
player_observations.Frank: Subtly nudged the table in the right direction more with supportive comments and team preferences than with loud, declarative reads.
player_observations.Grace: Used her initial leadership to establish social capital and then didn’t squander it with wild or erratic accusations.
player_observations.Henry: Projected confidence in his decisions, especially around team formation, in a way that looked more like informed good than reckless evil.
player_observations.Jack: Seemed to weigh prior mission info carefully when building Mission 4, indicating a more analytical than impulsive style.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistent with my reads, trusted the right people on the critical mission 4 team, and avoided drawing too much suspicion, which helped protect Merlin. I could improve by engaging more explicitly in deduction after mission 3’s double-fail to better pressure evil and narrow down the assassin options for endgame.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very trustworthy, low-drama good style; being on three early teams (including the failed one) without triggering much suspicion shows she projects reliability well.
player_observations.Bob: Classic Percival energy: actively protective of perceived Merlin candidates and pushed for safe team comps without over-explaining, which helped keep evil guessing.
player_observations.Charlie: As assassin, blended in reasonably well early but the double-fail on mission 3 made their positioning riskier; stayed assertive enough to seem ‘helpful’ without over-claiming info.
player_observations.Diana: Morgana play was subtle and coordination-focused, trying to create plausible Merlin-like vibes without being too loud, which kept the good team’s info a bit muddled.
player_observations.Eve: Solid, cooperative good presence; contributed to making the mission 4 team feel safe and didn’t overreact to the mission 3 fail, which helped stabilize the table.
player_observations.Frank: Very controlled Merlin game—gave just enough directional nudges (especially around team 2 and 4) without hard-pushing reads that would expose themselves.
player_observations.Grace: As Mordred, set a strong tone early with a clean mission 1 and used that trust well; tended to lead in a confident but not domineering way that made early evil success believable.
player_observations.Henry: Came across as straightforwardly good, particularly through clean participation in missions 1–3; his natural ‘good aura’ made him a plausible Merlin target for the assassin.
player_observations.Iris: As Oberon, their signals felt a bit off-tempo with the rest of evil, especially around the mission 3 fail; the lack of visible coordination made their alignment hard to read but also less influential.
